title: IRC Archive for channel #xwiki on 12 November 2013 - XWiki
content:
<sdumitriu1> has quit  
00:43 <abusenius> has quit  
00:47 <vmassol> has quit  
01:35 <vmassol> has joined #xwiki

01:50 <vmassol> has joined #xwiki

03:53 <vmassol> has quit  
04:49 <vmassol> has joined #xwiki  
04:53 <vmassol> has quit  
05:49 <vmassol> has joined #xwiki  
05:53 <vmassol> has quit  
06:42 <vmassol> has joined #xwiki  
06:44 <vmassol1> has joined #xwiki  
06:44 <vmassol> has quit  
06:49 <vmassol1> has quit  
06:49 <vmassol> has joined #xwiki  
06:53 <vmassol> has quit  
06:55 <mflorea> has joined #xwiki  
07:26 <vmassol> has joined #xwiki  
08:29 <tmortagne> has joined #xwiki  
08:34 <mflorea> tmortagne: Good morning. Platform build is failing due to a compile error in one of the wikistream modules (in case you were not aware of it).  
08:36 <mflorea> vmassol: Good morning. What do we do when we revert a released commit with a jira issue. Do we create a new jira issue? We cannot reopen the jira issue because it was released.  
08:36 <vmassol> mflorea: good morning  
08:37 <vmassol> create a new issue indeed  
08:37 <mflorea> ok, thanks  
08:37 <mflorea> and I'll link the old one  
08:37 <vmassol> yep  
08:37 <vmassol> I think that's the cleanest  
08:37 <mflorea> me too  
08:37 <mflorea> the bad part is that we 'loose' comments (you have to go the original issue to read the first comments)  
08:38 <mflorea> but it's fine  
08:40 <tmortagne> mflorea: I think it's because of the issue with CLIRR on commons  
08:40 <mflorea> ok  
08:41 <tmortagne> I saw it but I don't understand why clirr fail, I do have the right ignore  
08:41 <vmassol> today is release day right?  
08:41 <vmassol> (actually was yesterday?)  
08:41 <vmassol> this what I see on http://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Roadmaps/WebHome  
08:42 <cjd> has joined #xwiki  
08:45 <tmortagne> should be better now  
08:45 <tmortagne> I have to go, back in 30 min  
08:59 <evalica> has joined #xwiki  
09:07 <mflorea> vmassol: I updated the release dates.  
09:07 <vmassol> ok so it's thursday on BFD day, not that nice but ok ;)  
09:10 <vmassol> seems that 5.2 was one of our worst release ever...  
09:10 <vmassol> full of regressions  
09:10 <cjd> > Need to release 5.2 because we have a lot of important regressions  
09:11 <cjd> and so it was  
09:11 <cjd> also good morning  
09:11 <vmassol> seems we're missing a lot of automated tests to prevent such regressions btw, we need to set up a test fwk that's both fast to execute and that can test stuff in integration easily  
09:11 <vmassol> gm cjd  
09:12 <cjd> what kinds of tests are you thinking?  
09:12 <vmassol> tests that bypass the DB+container  
09:12 <cjd> mmm  
09:13 <vmassol> but with which we can test templates and page rendering  
09:13 <vmassol> ie assert the HTML at least  
09:13 <cjd> mhm  
09:14 <cjd> java y u have to start slow :|  
09:14 <cjd> messes up the whole testing system  
09:14 <cjd> unless you init a jvm then fork() it for each test or something similar  
09:17 <vmassol> right now a func test takes 1-2 min to execute, we need to be able to do the same under 10 seconds, 1 second would be nice  
09:17 <cjd> cat ./files.txt | grep '/test/' | sed 's/\(.\*\)/cat \1/' | bash | wc -l  
09:17 <cjd> 114436  
09:17 <cjd> 114k loc of unit tests in platform  
09:18 <cjd> user@ubnta8:~/wrk/cjdns$ find ./ -name '\*\_test.c' -exec cat {} \; | wc -l  
09:18 <cjd> 5132  
09:18 <cjd> real 0m 2.464s  
09:19 <cjd> linear scale by LoC is 54.94 seconds for unit tests  
09:19 <cjd> ok that was off topic  
09:19 <cjd> but it's a nice target to shoot for since we know it's attainable  
09:19 <vmassol> it's not  
09:20 <cjd> why not? java slow?  
09:20 <cjd> xD  
09:20 <vmassol> my 1000000000 tests run under 1s  
09:20 <vmassol> in java  
09:20 <vmassol> cjdns is very slow  
09:20 <vmassol> as a comparison  
09:21 <vmassol> is c slow?  
09:21 <cjd> billion tests?  
09:21 <vmassol> yup  
09:21 <cjd> 114,436 lines of test code?  
09:21 <vmassol> it's an empty for loop  
09:21 <vmassol> runs very fast  
09:22 <cjd> well yeah, you can't guarantee linear scaling because of fuzz tests and other things which are either fast or slow per LoC  
09:22 <cjd> but LoC is a nicer metric than nothing  
09:23 <cjd> anyway re fast testing, my gut instinct is that we need to do something not normal to get reasonable test times  
09:24 <cjd> EG: bring up a wiki engine, then jump out of the jvm and fire a fork() syscall before running each test  
09:25 <cjd> fork() is effectively free so you get N tests for the setup cost of 1  
09:37 <mflorea> tmortagne: ping  
09:37 <andrewmcveigh|wo> has joined #xwiki  
09:47 <Denis1> has joined #xwiki  
09:48 <Denis1> is now known as <Denis>  
09:50 <tmortagne> mflorea: pong  
09:50 <mflorea> I have this app http://extensions.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Extension/Collection+Application  
09:50 <mflorea> I update the extension using the refresh icon after "Extension imported from repository maven-xwiki"  
09:51 <tmortagne> and it does not work ?  
09:51 <mflorea> but dependencies are not added  
09:51 <mflorea> I'm going to debug locally  
09:51 <tmortagne> mflorea: I had the same kind of issue with another extension and was impossible to reproduce locally, that's why I asked for a xwiki.org clone  
09:52 <mflorea> ah, ok  
09:52 <tmortagne> will try to debug those issue today  
09:52 <tmortagne> needed to do that since a while anyway for another issue (extension saved without any modification only on xwiki.org)  
09:54 <gdelhumeau> has joined #xwiki  
09:56 <KermitTheFragger> has joined #xwiki  
10:35 <tmortagne> sburjan`: could you remind me the extension you were not able to update on extensions.xwiki.org ?  
10:48 <lucaa> has joined #xwiki  
10:48 <vmassol> cjd: please see XE-1341  
10:48 <vmassol> would be great if you could find some time to look at this issue  
10:54 <tmortagne> vmassol: good news, as you can see I enabled (definitely) the extensions update scheduler  
10:54 <vmassol> ah great :)  
10:55 <tmortagne> looks like the classes on xwiki.org were not up to date  
10:55 <vmassol> so we can remove the step from the release plan now?  
10:55 <tmortagne> yes  
10:55 <tmortagne> well  
10:55 <vmassol> ok I'll let you do it ;)  
10:55 <tmortagne> we can still force it during release  
10:55 <tmortagne> just no need to enable/disbale the schdeduler  
10:56 <vmassol> ok…  
10:56 <tmortagne> the scheduler only run once a day  
10:56 <tmortagne> so if you don't run it there is a big chance you will anounce a release and extensions.xwiki.org won't be up to date  
10:57 <camil7> has joined #xwiki  
10:59 <tmortagne> vmassol: for some reason we get IRC bot notification 1 or 2 minutes after the actual save  
11:00 <vmassol> well the bot on the xwiki side will receive it immediatly  
11:00 <vmassol> so I guess it's the time IRC will take to receive and display it  
11:01 <vmassol> that's long though  
11:01 <tmortagne> and this is new, we don't seem to have the same issue with our messages  
11:02 <KermitTheFragger> has quit  
11:03 <vmassol> just tested tmortagne  
11:03 <vmassol> and the message was received instantaneously  
11:03 <vmassol> (on this channel)  
11:03 <tmortagne> maybe it was temporary  
11:03 <vmassol> the roadmap page change  
11:03 <KermitTheFragger> has joined #xwiki  
11:03 <vmassol> maybe  
11:04 <vmassol> bb in 15mn  
11:05 <Slashman> has joined #xwiki  
11:13 <tmortagne> mflorea: the issue with http://extensions.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Extension/Collection+Application does not seems to be in the repository importer, look like for some reason AETHER does not see the dependencies in the pom, debugging locally  
11:14 <tmortagne> I don't see anything wrong by looking at http://maven.xwiki.org/releases/org/xwiki/contrib/application-collection-ui/1.0/application-collection-ui-1.0.pom  
11:14 <mflorea> could be related to scope:runtime?  
11:14 <tmortagne> well except the fact that it's not usong the right version variable ?  
11:14 <tmortagne> s/?/;)/  
11:14 <tmortagne> commons instead of platform  
11:14 <tmortagne> but that's not the issue here  
11:15 <tmortagne> I don't think it's related to scope runtime, that's the scope we use in XE itself  
11:15 <tmortagne> in any case there is a bug  
11:15 <mflorea> and the version should be good because otherwise I couldn't release  
11:16 <tmortagne> it's good because commons is the same as platform  
11:16 <tmortagne> but it's not very clean  
11:16 <tmortagne> I did not say it was the issue  
11:17 <tmortagne> ha looks like we are not using scope runtime in XE anymore, anyway we are using it in many other xars  
11:17 <tmortagne> and in XE we are still using it for oldcore  
11:20 <ekarlso> has quit  
11:21 <ekarlso> has joined #xwiki  
11:24 <sburjan> has joined #xwiki  
11:24 <gdelhumeau> Hi.  
11:25 <gdelhumeau> On a local build, when I export a XAR, in the XML I have strange '' characters at the end of every line  
11:25 <gdelhumeau> and the character ">" is not escaped anymore  
11:25 <gdelhumeau> do you know about it?  
11:28 <tmortagne> gdelhumeau: you sure it's every lines ?  
11:28 <tmortagne> could you paste what you have exactly ?  
11:36 <tmortagne> gdelhumeau: I have to go, will be back in 1 or 2 hours

11:44 <cjd> gdelhumeau: your client is still printing out that buffer you pasted because IRC has a 1 line per second limit, just disconnect and reconnect  
11:44 <gdelhumeau>   <content>{{velocity}}

11:44 <gdelhumeau> #set ($WikiManager = $services.wiki)  
11:44 <gdelhumeau> #set ($Exception = $WikiManager.lastException)

11:45 <gdelhumeau> has quit  
11:45 <gdelhumeau\_> has joined #xwiki  
11:45 <gdelhumeau\_> Sorry !!!

11:45 <gdelhumeau\_> the good paste was: http://hastebin.com/yokahuyora.xml

11:46 <cjd> but sdumitriu has screwey channel modes locked in ;)  
11:47 <cjd> weird, I don't think  is legal  
11:48 <cjd> ahh ok  
11:48 <cjd>  is a \r  
11:48 <cjd> which means you're using windows \:D/  
11:49 <cjd> > does not need to be escaped, probably a new version of the XML encoder is nolonger escaping it  
11:49 <cjd> < is the one that is important  
11:49 <cjd> the inclusion of \r is a little more annoying, xwiki probably ought to convert XWikiDocument content to \n terminated to avoid that

17:24 <sdumitriu> cjd, mflorea, tmortagne, gdelhumeau\_: Re: \r\n endings, the HTML standard does require \r\n, but our XAR export is not HTML so it could use any line ending we want, as long as it is consistent  
17:24 <sdumitriu> Personally I don't like \r\n  
17:24 <sdumitriu> So we can use \n globally, including in the textual fields  
17:25 <sdumitriu> On the other hand, XML uses \n as the standard line ending  
17:26 <sdumitriu> So big +1 for always using \n in the XML sources  
17:26 <sdumitriu> http://www.w3.org/TR/xml/#sec-line-ends  
17:29 <sdumitriu> HTML5 allows anything: http://www.w3.org/TR/html5/syntax.html#newlines
